verses.text: Now the whole earth had one language and the same words.
verses.comment: This verse sets the scene for the Tower of Babel narrative, emphasizing human unity before division. Unity in language symbolizes a potential for both good and prideful rebellion.

verses.text: And as people migrated from the east, they found a plain in the land of Shinar and settled there.
verses.comment: Shinar is commonly understood as Mesopotamia. The eastward migration points to the continuous movement and settling of humanity after the flood.

verses.text: They said to one another, 'Come, let us make bricks and bake them thoroughly.' They had brick for stone, and tar for mortar.
verses.comment: Use of bricks and tar shows technological advance. Humanity’s cooperation is highlighted, hinting at human potential when united—a theme reexamined in Pentecost (Acts 2:1-11).

verses.text: Then they said, 'Come, let us build ourselves a city, and a tower whose top will reach into heaven, and let us make a name for ourselves, lest we be scattered over the face of the whole earth.'
verses.comment: Desire for self-glorification and autonomy contradicts God's command to fill the earth. The tower represents human reach for the divine on their own terms. This foreshadows the human tendency to seek salvation apart from divine grace.

verses.text: But the LORD came down to see the city and the tower that the sons of men had built.
verses.comment: God ‘coming down’ is anthropomorphic, highlighting His personal engagement with humanity. Just as later Christ would enter the world, here the divine presence addresses human ambitions directly.

verses.text: And the LORD said, 'Behold, they are one people, and they all have one language. This is only the beginning of what they will do. Nothing they plan will be impossible for them.'
verses.comment: God recognizes human unity’s potential for both good and evil. The subtle hint is that true unity, later restored at Pentecost, is only safe under divine guidance.

verses.text: 'Come, let Us go down and confuse their language, so that they will not understand one another’s speech.'
verses.comment: 'Let Us' again hints at divine plurality, often interpreted as foreshadowing Trinitarian revelation later in Scripture. Pentecost reverses linguistic division.

verses.text: So the LORD scattered them from there over the face of all the earth, and they stopped building the city.
verses.comment: God’s intervention to scatter foreshadows the later expansion of God’s people for the sake of witness. Centralization is disrupted to fulfill God’s will.

verses.text: Therefore its name was called Babel, because there the LORD confused the language of all the earth. From there the LORD scattered them abroad over the face of all the earth.
verses.comment: ‘Babel’ sounds like the Hebrew for ‘confusion’. A contrast is seen between Babel’s confusion and Pentecost’s unity. Divine intervention both judges and opens the path for ordered unity under God.

verses.text: These are the generations of Shem: Shem was one hundred years old when he fathered Arpachshad two years after the flood.
verses.comment: Genealogies connect this narrative to the wider story of redemption, leading to Abraham and ultimately to Christ (cf. Luke 3:36). The succession shows God’s continued providence.

verses.text: After he fathered Arpachshad, Shem lived five hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Longevity signals the continuity of the early post-flood generations. Lineage is vital for the eventual fulfillment of God’s promises to humanity.

verses.text: When Arpachshad had lived thirty-five years, he fathered Shelah.
verses.comment: The genealogical structure is essential for tracing the promise that will culminate in Christ.

verses.text: After he fathered Shelah, Arpachshad lived four hundred and three years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: ‘Other sons and daughters’ indicates the vast expansion of mankind, though the line of promise remains with the named descendants.

verses.text: When Shelah had lived thirty years, he fathered Eber.
verses.comment: Eber is considered the ancestor of the Hebrews, linking the narrative to Israel’s identity.

verses.text: After he fathered Eber, Shelah lived four hundred and three years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Continues the pattern of long lifespans decreasing over generations—a theological note suggesting the effects of sin on creation.

verses.text: When Eber had lived thirty-four years, he fathered Peleg.
verses.comment: Peleg’s generation is noted for the earth’s division—a possible reference to Babel’s scattering.

verses.text: After he fathered Peleg, Eber lived four hundred and thirty years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Repetition of formulaic genealogy emphasizes God’s faithfulness through generations.

verses.text: When Peleg had lived thirty years, he fathered Reu.
verses.comment: The slow progression of generations leads towards the family of Abraham.

verses.text: After he fathered Reu, Peleg lived two hundred and nine years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: The lifespans are now declining, observing the trend after the flood.

verses.text: When Reu had lived thirty-two years, he fathered Serug.
verses.comment: Traces Christ’s lineage through the generations, fulfilling the promise.

verses.text: After he fathered Serug, Reu lived two hundred and seven years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Another repetition, again marking the gradual decrease in lifespans.

verses.text: When Serug had lived thirty years, he fathered Nahor.
verses.comment: Nahor’s line brings us one step closer to Abraham, whose covenant with God will shape salvation history.

verses.text: After he fathered Nahor, Serug lived two hundred years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Continues the genealogical context, stressing stable inheritance of promise.

verses.text: When Nahor had lived twenty-nine years, he fathered Terah.
verses.comment: Terah is the father of Abraham, establishing the transition from genealogy to God’s special calling and election.

verses.text: After he fathered Terah, Nahor lived one hundred and nineteen years and had other sons and daughters.
verses.comment: Terah’s significance is heightened as father of Abraham, setting the stage for the Covenant.

verses.text: When Terah had lived seventy years, he fathered Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
verses.comment: Abram (later Abraham) will become the recipient of the promise, demonstrating God's election and preparation for the coming Redeemer.

verses.text: Now these are the generations of Terah: Terah fathered Abram, Nahor, and Haran; and Haran fathered Lot.
verses.comment: The family connections foreshadow the future journeys and trials of Abraham and Lot, showing that God’s plan involves concrete families and communities.

verses.text: Haran died before his father Terah in the land of his birth, in Ur of the Chaldeans.
verses.comment: Ur of the Chaldeans is an important historical and cultural setting. The death of Haran before Terah signals loss and transition, soon leading to Abraham’s call.

verses.text: Abram and Nahor took wives. The name of Abram’s wife was Sarai, and the name of Nahor’s wife was Milcah, daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah and Iscah.
verses.comment: Genealogical details stress the importance of lineage; marriage within family lines protected inheritance and calling.

verses.text: Now Sarai was barren; she had no child.
verses.comment: Sarai’s barrenness sets up God’s miraculous intervention, a frequent motif illustrating that salvation comes by God's initiative, not human effort.

verses.text: Terah took his son Abram, his grandson Lot, son of Haran, and his daughter-in-law Sarai, his son Abram’s wife, and they went out together from Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the land of Canaan. But when they came to Haran, they settled there.
verses.comment: The journey prefigures the call of Abraham and the first movement towards the Promised Land—a typological foreshadowing of later spiritual journeys and pilgrimages.

verses.text: Terah lived two hundred and five years, and Terah died in Haran.
verses.comment: Terah’s death marks the start of Abraham’s central role. This concluding note transitions from genealogy to direct interaction with God’s covenantal promise.
